I am currently studying for a Master of Business Data Analytics at the Faculty of Business and Economics, Monash University. I am particularly interested in machine learning and predictive modeling.
Throughout my studies, I have developed skills in using R and tools such as tidyverse for data cleaning and wrangling, exploratory data analysis, modeling, and visualization, and I use Quarto to write analytical reports. title: Listening to Rivers Through Data
text:
Understanding how the model works
To understand the study‚Äôs key insight, we first need to look at how its model works. When studying nitrate changes in rivers, we‚Äôre dealing with data that are both nonlinear and temporal ‚Äî relationships that bend and fluctuate over time. A simple linear regression can‚Äôt capture both at once. To bridge that gap, the researchers built a two-step framework using GAM and GAMM, which together reveal smooth environmental patterns while accounting for time dependence.
The first layer, a GAM (Generalized Additive Model), replaces straight-line predictors with flexible smooth functions.
\[
\text{Nitrate}_t = \beta_0 + s_1(\text{Temp}_t) + s_2(\text{Cond}_t) + s_3(\text{DO}_t)
+ s_4(\text{Turb}_t) + s_5(\text{Elev}_t) + \varepsilon_t
\]
To capture short-term memory in the data, the second layer adds a time-series component ‚Äî the GAMM (Generalized Additive Mixed Model):
\[
\text{Nitrate}_t = \beta_0 + \sum_i s_i(X_{i,t}) + \phi\,\text{Nitrate}_{t-1} + \varepsilon_t
\]
This autoregressive term œï corrects for temporal autocorrelation, ensuring that the model respects how today‚Äôs water chemistry depends on yesterday‚Äôs. Together, these two parts make the framework both flexible and robust.
Together, these two components form the core logic of the framework ‚Äî but the model‚Äôs strength also comes from how carefully it was designed and validated across sites.

What the model reveals
Using this combined GAM‚ÄìGAMM approach, the researchers explained nearly 99% of the variation in nitrate concentration. The result is methodologically elegant yet practically efficient ‚Äî showing that relatively simple models, when properly structured, can capture complex biogeochemical dynamics with impressive precision.

Even though these five factors mattered everywhere, their influence varied from site to site. For instance, in one river, short-term memory ‚Äî the river‚Äôs own recent history ‚Äî played a big role; in another, the physical conditions dominated.
In other words, rivers share some ‚Äúuniversal rules,‚Äù but each has its own accent. Figure¬†1 shows how each variable contributes differently across the three sites. At Arikaree, for instance, the autoregressive term accounts for roughly 25% of the variation in nitrate, whereas at Lewis Run, all five variables play a substantial role. This contrast highlights that reliable monitoring depends not only on the common drivers shared across rivers, but also on local conditions that shape how each variable matters. Overall, these results illustrate that while some patterns are universal, local context can strongly influence the relative importance of each factor.

title: Listening to Rivers Through Data
text:
Key Technical Details
Three design choices make this modelling framework both reliable and transferable. First, the authors validated their models across sites ‚Äî training on one river and testing on the others. This cross-site validation confirmed that the model‚Äôs predictive accuracy holds under different climatic and land-use conditions.
Second, they filtered variables for collinearity, excluding measures such as pH, fDOM, and discharge to avoid redundancy. This ensured that each remaining variable captured distinct physical or chemical information rather than overlapping effects.
Finally, the model accounted for temporal autocorrelation using an AR(1) structure, where each 15-minute observation was partly informed by the previous one. This step allowed the model to reflect short-term persistence in water chemistry and helped raise its explanatory power to 99%.
